articles.headline: An Emerging Hispanic Voice Defends Her ‘Maids’
articles.snippet: Eva Longoria works as an executive producer of “Devious Maids,” about Hispanic domestics, while she grows as a public figure.
articles.abstract: Eva Longoria works as an executive producer of “Devious Maids,” about Hispanic domestics, while she grows as a public figure.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At a premiere party at the Spanish-colonial-style Bel-Air Bay Club last week for the new Lifetime show “Devious Maids,” the center of attention was not the five actresses who play the lead characters, Latina maids who cook, clean and scheme while looking after wealthy white families in Beverly Hills.

articles.headline: Senate Vote on Border Gives Push to Immigration Overhaul
articles.snippet: The Senate, in a major step toward a bipartisan immigration overhaul, endorsed an amendment that would nearly double the Border Patrol force.
articles.abstract: The Senate, in a major step toward a bipartisan immigration overhaul, endorsed an amendment that would nearly double the Border Patrol force.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The bipartisan push to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws took a major step forward Monday evening when the Senate endorsed a proposal to substantially bolster security along the nation’s southern borders as part of a measure that would provide a path to citizenship for 11 million undocumented immigrants already in the country.

articles.headline: Economists Are Asking: Did Bernanke Tip Fed’s Hand?
articles.snippet: In a perfect world, the Fed’s communications strategy should make the markets less erratic, but with investors hanging on every word from the Fed, volatility seems to have grown worse.
articles.abstract: In a perfect world, the Fed’s communications strategy should make the markets less erratic, but with investors hanging on every word from the Fed, volatility seems to have grown worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is Ben Bernanke being too chatty?

articles.headline: Credit Warnings Offer World a Peek Into China’s Secretive Banks
articles.snippet: The Chinese central bank’s crackdown against excessive lending has put focus on a banking sector that some say is hiding piles of bad debt.
articles.abstract: The Chinese central bank’s crackdown against excessive lending has put focus on a banking sector that some say is hiding piles of bad debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s hidden banking system is coming out of the shadows as the government seeks to rein in the excessive lending that it fears could spin out of control.

articles.headline: Exit From the Bond Market Is Turning Into a Stampede
articles.snippet: The sell-off prompted some calming words from a Fed official about its support for the economy — and by extension, the bond market.
articles.abstract: The sell-off prompted some calming words from a Fed official about its support for the economy — and by extension, the bond market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street never thought it would be this bad.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Supreme Court Raises Bar to Prove Job Discrimination
articles.snippet: In one decision, the court tightened the definition of what constitutes a workplace supervisor; in another, a higher standard of proof was set for plaintiffs.
articles.abstract: In one decision, the court tightened the definition of what constitutes a workplace supervisor; in another, a higher standard of proof was set for plaintiffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: In two decisions issued on Monday, the Supreme Court effectively made it harder for workers to prove that they had suffered employment discrimination.

articles.headline: Assange, Back in News, Never Left U.S. Radar
articles.snippet: Julian Assange and his organization, WikiLeaks, are being investigated by at least four United States government agencies, along with a grand jury that has subpoenaed witnesses.
articles.abstract: Julian Assange and his organization, WikiLeaks, are being investigated by at least four United States government agencies, along with a grand jury that has subpoenaed witnesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: In June 2011, Ogmundur Jonasson, Iceland’s minister of the interior at the time, received an urgent message from the authorities in the United States. It said that “there was an imminent attack on Icelandic government databases” by hackers, and that the F.B.I. would send agents to investigate, Mr. Jonasson said in a telephone interview.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: U.S. Civil Charges Against Corzine Are Seen as Near
articles.snippet: The federal agency that regulated the brokerage firm MF Global before it collapsed in 2011 plans to sue Jon S. Corzine, its former chief executive.
articles.abstract: The federal agency that regulated the brokerage firm MF Global before it collapsed in 2011 plans to sue Jon S. Corzine, its former chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are poised to sue Jon S. Corzine over the collapse of MF Global and the brokerage firm’s misuse of customer money during its final days, a blowup that rattled Wall Street and cast a spotlight on Mr. Corzine, the former New Jersey governor who ran the firm until its bankruptcy in 2011.

articles.headline: With Snowden in Middle, U.S. and Russia Joust, and Cool Off
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday appeared to rule out sending Edward J. Snowden back to the United States, as Moscow and Washington tried to prevent a cold-war-style standoff.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday appeared to rule out sending Edward J. Snowden back to the United States, as Moscow and Washington tried to prevent a cold-war-style standoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday appeared to rule out sending Edward J. Snowden back to the United States to face espionage charges, leaving him in limbo even as Moscow and Washington seemed to be making an effort to prevent a cold-war-style standoff from escalating.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn, Ellen Barry and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Supreme Court Invalidates Key Part of Voting Rights Act
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court split along ideological lines with its ruling that Congress had not provided adequate justification for subjecting the states, mostly in the South, to federal oversight.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court split along ideological lines with its ruling that Congress had not provided adequate justification for subjecting the states, mostly in the South, to federal oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday effectively struck down the heart of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 by a 5-to-4 vote, freeing nine states, mostly in the South, to change their election laws without advance federal approval.
